title: England women's team are showing male Three Lions counterparts the way, admits FA chief exec
text:
Sport England women's team are showing male Three Lions counterparts the way, admits FA chief exec Martin Glenn hails squad that finished third at 2015 World Cup as "one of the best in terms of team spirit I have seen — and we will get there with the men" Share England women's beat the USA this month — the men failed against tiny Iceland last summer (Photo: Splash News / Getty Images) Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
FA chief executive Martin Glenn believes England’s women footballers have a stronger “team identity” than their male counterparts . 
The Three Lions supremo spoke as the FA unveiled plans to double the number of girls and women playing football to nearly six million by 2020. 
The Lionesses pulled off the best performance by a senior England side since the 1966 World Cup-winning team two years ago as they beat Germany for the first time to finish third at the Women’s World Cup in ­Canada. 
England’s men suffered a humiliating exit from Euro 2016 at the first knockout stage against tiny Iceland. 
The women also beat the USA, the No1 ranked team in the world, on their own turf in New Jersey just over a week ago. Laura Bassett, Claire Rafferty and co flew the flag with pride at Canada 2015... (Photo: FIFA via Getty) ...as they finished third at the World Cup under boss Mark Sampson (Photo: FIFA via Getty) 
Gareth Southgate, who names his squad on Thursday, is tasked with rebuilding team morale. 
Glenn said: “The women – and I saw it in Canada which gives us great hope – have a stronger sense of team identity as to who they are. 
"Through a­dversity, ­because we have heard their stories, it has never been easy. You get strength through a­dversity. And we have worked hard with sports psychiatrists and the like to create that ­identity. 
“We have got in Gareth someone who wants to do the same with the senior men’s team and I am r­eally ­confident we will have that. 
“What we have is a bit of a void. If you ask an England men’s player, 'What medal would you really want to have?’ It’s a World Cup winners’ medal. Undoubtedly. There is a not a lack of passion or desire. The following summer, Jamie Vardy and the blokes had a dismal Euro 2016... (Photo: Andy Stenning/Daily Mirror) ...going out at the first knockout hurdle to a nation with the population of Leicester (Photo: Getty) 
“But there is a bit of a gulf in what they do stand for. 
"I think the bulldog spirit, go out and kill or whatever – it doesn’t work for such a diverse group of players or this generation of them. So the England women’s team is one of the best in terms of team spirit I have seen and we will get there with the men. 
"With ­Gareth, he ­absolutely gets it.” 
Head of Women’s ­football, Baroness Sue Campbell, aims to have competitive ­England teams across all age ­levels and ­revealed the FA will target “eight key priority areas”. Part of Southgate's brief is to improve the team spirit within the male squad (Photo: Getty) 
They include “a ­sustainable high performance system to produce world-class players”, “changing ­perceptions and social barriers” and ­enhancing the profile of the women’s team. 
Arsenal and England ­defender Alex Scott revealed she worked in the laundry of the Gunners’ men’s team to earn the money to make her way in the game. 
She said: “It’s not been easy to get where we have. 
"That’s what always kept us as a close group, to achieve ­something together. It’s not about ‘me’. It’s about all of us. You had Casey Stoney ­coming out and announcing she was gay, instead of hiding it. You had me come from a council estate in east London. Martin Glenn and Alex Scott with local schoolchildren at Monday's strategy launch (Photo: The FA via Getty) 
“My mum was never on the sidelines with me, because she was out trying to support me to get the football boots. In meeting rooms, there’s been tears because of the ­struggles we’ve been through. We’ve always wanted this. 
“I can laugh that I worked in Arsenal men’s laundry with Vic Akers because I needed some extra money to go to my ­training ­sessions. I’m proud of it. I had to do it to ­become a footballer. 
“We have to keep that culture, keep passing on those messages, show what was fought to get to our position — and not take it for granted.” poll loading Do you agree the England women show more team spirit than the men? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
